document_data.name: Viperfish
document_data.refs2e: <ref group="note" name="size">While the stat-block for this creature only lists its size as "Huge", the descriptive text for it refers to it as ranging in size from {{SI|1|in}} and a half to {{SI|20|ft}}. Therefore, it is more accurate to say that these creatures range in size from "Small" to "Huge".
document_data.mainbody: '''Viperfish''' were an uncommon predatory species of deep sea [[fish]]
document_data.Description:
Viperfish varied considerably in size. At their smallest they measured around {{SI|1|in}} and a half, with the largest natural size being around {{SI|6|ft|long=yes}}. Some more monstrous specimens of this species were found to grow as large as {{SI|20|ft|long=yes}} in length.

One of the most distinguishing features was the long, fang-like teeth that filled their large mouths. These teeth were designed so as to fold into their mouths with ease whenever a viperfish needed to close it, acting as bars to prison prey trapped and to prevent a viperfish from losing their grasp on any prey that turned out to be larger than they could reasonably handle.

These creatures were also distinguished by the bio-luminescence emitted by circular spots along dual rows on either side of their bodies, as well as by patches within their mouths. And the whip-like growths that protruded from the area of their head analogous to a chin. A select view viperfish were noted as having special whip-like growths that functioned similarly to tentacles, allowing them to constrict their prey.
document_data.Abilities: These fish sensed where they were going both by sight, aided by their bio-luminescence, and from their whip-like growths. These growths acted sort of like antennae, extensions of their lateral senses that could detect nearby movement within the ocean.
document_data.Combat:
[[File:Viperfish.png|thumb|''The fish.'']]
Viperfish were active hunters that preyed upon other unsuspecting creatures of the deep sea, luring them in with their bio-luminescence. They typically resorted to swallowing their prey whole. Attacking them to free captured prey was ill-advised, as doing so was more than likely to injure the prey as well.
document_data.History: Over the years many attempts were made to study these peculiar fish alive, but these attempts mostly wound up fruitless as specimens tended to die less than half a [[bell (time)|bell]] after being captured. This continued to be the case as late as the 15{{th}} century [[DR]].

Ecology.Diet: These creatures were a carnivorous species that sometimes tried to prey upon creatures larger than themselves.
Ecology.Usage: The flesh of a viperfish was edible, though it was not particularly pleasant.
